statement.tex: \text{What would be the equivalent roster form}\\ \text{of the following set?}\\ \quad C = \lbrace x:x^2+7x+10 = 0,x\in\mathbb{N} \rbrace

step.tex: \begin{tabular}{|c|c|} \hline \text{Type} & \text{Meaning} \\ \hline \text{Set builder} & \lbrace x:\texttt{ list of conditions on x}\rbrace \\ \hline \text{Roster} & \lbrace a_1,a_2, a_3, \ldots \rbrace \\ \hline \end{tabular}

\begin{tabular}{|c|c|} \hline \text{Type} & \text{Meaning} \\ \hline \text{Set builder} & \lbrace a_1,a_2, a_3, \ldots \rbrace \\ \hline \text{Roster} & \lbrace x:\texttt{ list of conditions on x}\rbrace \\ \hline \end{tabular}
step.reason: \textbf{Roster is just another word for a list.}\\ \text{So, when you list out all the elements of a set}\\ \text{you are expressing the set in }\underline{\text{Roster notation}}. \\ \text{But if instead you list the conditions that} \\ \text{elements of a set must satisfy, then you're}\\ \text{using the }\underline{\text{Set builder notation}}.

step.context: \text{Given that }C = \lbrace x:x^2+7x+10 = 0,x\in\mathbb{N} \rbrace \\ \text{is set-builder notation, is the following correct?}
step.tex: \text{No 'x' satisfies both the conditions }\\ \text{mentioned in C. Hence, }C = \lbrace\rbrace = \phi.
step.reason: \begin{align} x^2+7x+10 &= 0\implies (x+2)\cdot (x+5) = 0 \\ \implies x &= -2, -5 \end{align} \\ \textbf{But don't forget the second condition!}\\ \text{Neither of }x=-2\text{ nor }x=-5\in\mathbb{N}.\\ \text{Hence, C is an empty set. Or, }C = \phi.
